pull.title: utils: Use _wfopen and _wfreopen on Windows
pull.body: The fopen function does not support unicode filename on Windows, so use Windows specific function do deal with it.

events.body: @Empact They are the same if we ignore the errno.

issue.title: Filename and command line encoding issue on Windows
issue.body:
This issue tracks the TODO list in order to fix the encoding issue on Window.

Currently Bitcoin Core uses the ANSI encoding on Windows so that it would affected by user's language settings, they might not able to open some non-ASCII name files.

You can test all these changes in #13787 (includes leveldb changes)

Open PRs:
------------
- [ ] Package the Windows installer in unicode mode (NSIS 3+) (#13827, Up for grab, or wait for Ubuntu 20.04 gitian builder host)

Merged PRs:
--------------
- [x] Create the startup shortcut file in unicode mode (#13734)
- [x] Make filelock work on unicode filename (#13862)
- [x] Use `_wfopen` instead of `fopen` on Windows to pass unicode filename (#13866)
- [x] Make boost `fs::path` `.string()` to be always encoded to utf-8 (#13877)
- [x] Wrap `ifstream` and `ofstream` to accept unicode filename. (#13878)
- [x] Get the command line arguments using unicode (#13883)
- [x] Make bdb read the filename using utf-8 (#13884)
- [x] Make `runCommand` works on unicode filename (#13886)
- [x] Convert all `(...)A` function to `(...)W` on Windows if it is related to filename or command line. (#13888)
- [x] Convert boost filesystem error messages from local multibyte to utf-8 (#14192)
- [x] Make leveldb read the filename using utf-8 (bitcoin-core/leveldb#18)

events.body: <!--e57a25ab6845829454e8d69fc972939a-->No more conflicts as of last run.

issue.title: utils: drop boost::interprocess::file_lock
issue.body:
boost::interprocess::file_lock cannot open the files that contain characters which cannot be parsed by the user's code page on Windows.

This PR is seperated from #13426 for easier review.

issue.title: Move src/tinyformat.h to src/tinyformat/tinyformat.h
issue.body:
For consistency with other bundled dependencies. Having it in the top-level
directory makes it clear that it is a library that we're including
rather than a file that is a part of the project.

tinyformat/tinyformat.h and tinyformat/README.md are drawn from the existing
sha reference:
https://github.com/c42f/tinyformat/tree/689695cf58700e6defe3741829564cd682d5ae57

Existing modifications to tinyformat are moved to utilstrprintf.h, clearly
separating upstream and project code.

This includes changes in:
695041e4952ea40e0 - util: Update tinyformat
1b8fd35aadfad6a1e - Make tinyformat errors raise an exception instead of assert()ing
9b6d4c5cdc1ad7b12 - Move strprintf define to tinyformat.h
6e5fd003e04b81115 - Move `*Version()` functions to version.h/cpp
9eaa0afa6ec5d3dd0 - tinyformat: force USE_VARIADIC_TEMPLATES
b651270cd6bfdd6d7 - util: Throw tinyformat::format_error on formatting error

This does not include changes below, which are cosmetic or apparently unintentional:
64fb0ac016c7fd01c - Declare single-argument (non-converting) constructors "explicit"
4d9b4256d89d1f7c6 - Fix typos

Note I excluded only the tinyformat cpp from the boost lint checks out of an
abundance of caution - these files are not actually built into bitcoin so are
not at risk of pulling in unwanted dependencies, whereas the header, and other
dependencies might be.

issue.title: Include tinyformat as a subtree
issue.body:
This adds the existing c42f/tinyformat@689695c of tinyformat as a subtree, and extracts the modifications that had been made to a utilstrprintf.h wrapper file which is included instead of tinyformat.h directly.

The benefits being that this should be easier to verifiably update and clearer what changes are being introduced, while making it easier to identify tinyformat.h as a dependency rather than a project file, and apply special treatment relative to that fact.

This re-opens #13842

issue.title: Inline i64tostr and itostr
issue.body:
These methods don't give us much, and removing them removes utilstrencodings's
dependence on tinyformat

issue.title: Test for Windows encoding issue
issue.body: This PR removes unused Windows compatible path. Encoding issues has been solved.

issue.title: PSBT key path cleanups
issue.body:
This PR adds "key origin" (master fingeprint + key path) information to what is exposed from `SigningProvider`s, allowing this information to be used by the generic PSBT code instead of having the RPC pull it directly from the wallet.

This is also a preparation to having PSBT interact with output descriptors, which can then directly expose key origin information for the scripts they generate.

issue.title: Remove the boost/algorithm/string/case_conv.hpp dependency
issue.body:
This pull request removes the `boost/algorithm/string/case_conv.hpp` dependency from the project.

`boost/algorithm/string/case_conv.hpp` is included for the `boost::to_lower` and `boost::to_upper` template functions.

We can replace the calls to these functions with straightforward alternative implementations that use the C++ Standard Library, because the functions are called with `std::string` objects that use standard 7-bit ASCII characters as argument.

The refactored implementation should work without the explicit `static_cast<unsigned char>` cast and `unsigned char` lambda return type. Both have been added defensively and to be explicit. Especially in case of the former, behaviour is undefined (potentially result in a crash) if the `std::toupper` argument is not an `unsigned char`.

A potential alternative, maybe even preferred, implementation to address the `boost::to_lower` function call in `ParseNetwork(std::string)` could have been:

```c++
if (net == "ipv4" || net == "IPv4") return NET_IPV4;
if (net == "ipv6" || net == "IPv6") return NET_IPV6;
```
This alternative implementation would however change the external behaviour of `ParseNetwork(std::string)`.

This pull requests includes a unit test to validate the implementation of `ParseNetwork(std::string)`  prior and after the removal of the `case_conv.hpp` dependency.

`boost/algorithm/string/case_conv.hpp` has been removed from the `EXPECTED_BOOST_INCLUDES` in `test/lint/lint-includes.sh` because it is no longer required.

issue.title: [bugfix] Fix encoding issue for Windows
issue.body:
Fix #13103 
Fix #13754

From https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/13107#issuecomment-385141831, @laanwj suggested that we should keep our internal strings to be always utf-8 encoded.

This PR adds two C++17 compatible macros: `u8string` and `u8path`. The reason that I use macros is that developers might not want to pass second parameter `utf8` everytime when they call `string` or create `path` objects.

I tried to find all `string` methods and convert them to `u8string` except for external api calls. Also tried to convert explicit or implicit `path` to `u8path`. Tell me if you find something that I missed.

Required: bitcoin-core/leveldb#18

See #13787 for travis run result


Caution: The user must change their config file to be utf-8 encoded if the file contains any non-ascii characters in it. Before 0.18, they are read as ansi-encoded characters on Windows.
--

events.body: Update: use std codecvt instead of custom converter.

events.message:
utils: Use _wfopen and _wreopen on Windows

The fopen function does not support unicode filename on Windows, so use Windows specific function do deal with it

issue.title: utils: Add fstream wrapper to allow to pass unicode filename on Windows
issue.body:
If compiled with mingw, use glibc++ extension `stdio_filebuf` to open the file by `FILE*` instead of filename.

In other condition, we can use boost::fstream.

issue.title: Merge #19660, #19373, #19841, #13862, #13866, #17280, #17682 and partial #19326, #14978: Auxiliary Backports
issue.body:
## Overview

As part of https://github.com/dashpay/dash/pull/4025, component pull requests that are required by TorV3 logic are being broken down into branches wherever feasable. In anticipation of the merger of https://github.com/dashpay/dash/pull/4028, the preparation for the next round of dependencies for TorV3 (excluding https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/19687/commits/2bc207190e6f1818b04c9336f6e0d625b2a2a0ba, relies on #4028) 

## Contents

* Mostly merged bitcoin#19660: ("refactor: Make HexStr take a span" by laanwj)
  * See https://github.com/UdjinM6/dash/commit/6f7b52ac63a71d2706022ca58d69a1a622e0fa37, requires bitcoin#13557, reworded as "partial" though could be treated as merged
* Merge bitcoin#19373: ("refactor: Replace HexStr(o.begin(), o.end()) with HexStr(o)" by laanwj)
* Merge bitcoin#19841: ("Implement Keccak and SHA3_256" by sipa)
* Merge bitcoin#13862: ("utils: drop boost::interprocess::file_lock" by ken2812221) 
* Merge bitcoin#13866 ("utils: Use _wfopen and _wfreopen on Windows" by ken2812221) 
* Merge https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/17280 ("refactor: Change occurences of c_str() used with size() to data()" by laanwj)
  * Small nit, it also modifies `get_filesystem_error_message` (added in https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/14192 that relies on https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/14209, which in turn relies on https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/12954) that hasn't been implemented so that change was omitted

### Partials

* Merge #19326 ("Simplify hash.h interface using Spans" by sipa)
  * Excludes 2a2182c387f607cd8284f33890bd285a81077b7f, 02c4cc5c5ddf61f98ee366a4bea8abc26de492bd. Blocked by https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/17938
* Merge #14978 ("Factor out PSBT utilities from RPCs for use in GUI code; related refactoring" by gwillen)
  * Only contains 162ffefd2f562169725559906601c25c579aa91c to resolve merge conflict in https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/19687
## Disclosures

* Dash-specific changes may not have been tested, only compilation and successful tests has been ensured. Running the client on (a) testnet(s) may be necessary.
* Contains squashed patches 85ce71d759e2e3aa296e09ac3754914eaf230423, 6f7b52ac63a71d2706022ca58d69a1a622e0fa37, f6cf5478601048e9b681622eff7c8353be80866d and e39a095530af569590eeafbd903135151026990f by UdjinM6

issue.title: Solve filename and command line encoding issues on Windows
issue.body:
As the software is currently using the ANSI encoding on Windows, the user's language settings could affect the proper functioning of the node/wallet, to the point of not be able to open some non-ASCII name files and directories.

This solves the Windows encoding issues, completing the entire #13869 work path (and some other required backports). Enabling for example users that use non-english characters in directories and file names to be accepted.

Backported PRs:
* #12422.
* #12630.
* #13862.
* #13866.
* #13877.
* #13878.
* #13883.
* #13884.
* #13886.
* #13888.
* #14192.
* #13734.
* #14426.

This is built on top of other two PRs that i have open #2423 and #2369.
Solves old issues #940 and #2163.


TODO:
* Backport `assert_start_raises_init_error` and `ErrorMatch` in TestNode` (https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/12718)

comments.body: I find the &* unnecessarily complicated. Can you use utf8_string.data() or even the more usual c_str() instead that gives a direct pointer back.
Is this assert necessary? MultiByteToWideChar won't change the size of the string.
This avoid the unnecessary copy, `&*utf8_string.begin()` point to where the exact string data are. `c_str()` and `data()` is a copy of the string data.
They won't change, so that's why I use assert instead of a bunch of error handling.
nit: Make this include conditional on `WIN32`?
I didn't spot the size= part before the asset. Sorry :)
Not sure what implementation you are referring to but c_str and data have always returned the pointer to the internal data. Not a copy. Anyway it was just a nitpick. Thanks.
